title: 108_s2671
content: The "State Fiscal Relief Act of 2004" extends temporary state fiscal relief. The "State Fiscal Relief Act of 2004" extends temporary freeze of Medicaid FMAP for certain states, allowing maintenance of fiscal year 2004 FMAP for fiscal year 2005. The State Fiscal Relief Act of 2004 extends the freeze on Medicaid FMAP for certain states, maintaining the fiscal year 2004 FMAP for fiscal year 2005. Additionally, there is a temporary increase in Medicaid FMAP for all states for specific calendar quarters. The State Fiscal Relief Act of 2004 extends the freeze on Medicaid FMAP for certain states, maintaining the fiscal year 2004 FMAP for fiscal year 2005. There is also a temporary increase in Medicaid FMAP for all states for specific calendar quarters in fiscal year 2003 and 2004. The State Fiscal Relief Act of 2004 extends the freeze on Medicaid FMAP for certain states, maintaining the fiscal year 2004 FMAP for fiscal year 2005. Additionally, there is a temporary increase in Medicaid payments to territories for specific calendar quarters in fiscal year 2003 and 2004. The State Fiscal Relief Act of 2004 extends the freeze on Medicaid FMAP for certain states, maintaining the fiscal year 2004 FMAP for fiscal year 2005. There is also a temporary increase in Medicaid payments to territories for specific calendar quarters in fiscal year 2003 and 2004. Amendments are made to the Jobs and Growth Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003. The Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003 is amended to update various paragraphs for fiscal years 2004 and 2005. The Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003 is amended to update paragraphs for fiscal years 2004 and 2005 by changing the date from "October 1, 2004" to "January 1, 2005". SEC. 3. Transitional fund for implementing the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003. Section 1931(h) of the Social Security Act is amended to increase the specified percentage in section 1903(a)(7) for administrative expenditures. The Social Security Act is amended to increase the specified percentage for administrative expenditures. This includes limitations on additional Federal funds expended due to the application of the subsection. The Social Security Act is amended to increase the specified percentage for administrative expenditures, with a limit of $500,000,000 for fiscal year 1997 onwards. The Secretary must ensure equitable distribution of additional funds among states. Additional Federal funds expended due to this subsection for administrative expenditures are capped for the period starting October 1, 2004, and ending on the later of April 1, 2006, or the end of the first fiscal year quarter after benefits are first provided. The Social Security Act is amended to increase administrative expenditure percentage with a $500,000,000 limit from fiscal year 1997 onwards. Additional funds for benefits under the prescription drug program in part D of title XVIII are capped at $1,200,000,000, ensuring equitable distribution among states based on eligibility and dual eligible individuals.
